brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to assess the feasibility of exenatide infusion for the
      treatment of high blood sugars following acute brain injury.

clinical_study.brief_title: Intravenous Exenatide in Patients With Acute Brain Injury

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Adults ≥18 years

          -  Moderate to severe neurologically brain injured patients with subarachnoid hemorrhage
             (GCS ≤12) or severe traumatic brain injury (GCS <8) requiring and receives invasive
             intracranial multi-modal monitoring

          -  Blood glucose reading > 180 mg/dL and ≤300 mg/dL within first 48 hours of hospital
             admission

          -  Informed consent obtained via proxy

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Pregnant (verified by urine or serum pregnancy test within 24 hours of initiation of
             infusion) or lactating females

          -  Type 1 diabetes mellitus

          -  History of pancreatitis or risk factors for acute pancreatitis (i.e ethanol abuse,
             gall stones)

          -  Renal insufficiency defined as creatinine clearance (CrCL) < 45 mL/min

          -  Known history of gastroparesis

          -  History of surgery on stomach, esophagus or duodenum

          -  Diabetic Ketoacidosis or Hyperosmolar Hyperglycemic Nonketotic Syndrome

          -  Concurrent steroid use or planned post-operative steroid use

          -  History of organ transplantation

          -  Brain death or suspected imminent brain death within the next 72 hours

          -  Refractory intracranial hypertension defined as intracranial pressure (ICP) > 25 mmHg
             for greater than 15 minutes and refractory to medical intervention

          -  Currently enrolled in another investigational drug or device protocol

          -  Insulin infusion within 3 hours of study drug administration or confirmed long acting
             insulin or sulfonylurea use prior to admission within 24 hours of study drug
             administration

          -  Known allergy to exenatide

intervention.description: 50 ng/min IV for 30 minutes, then start 25 ng/min IV for a maximum duration of 48 hours

facility.name: University of North Carolina; UNC Medical Center

clinical_study.official_title: Intravenous Exenatide Infusion in Critically Ill Neurologic Injured Patients: A Proof of Concept Study

overall_official.affiliation: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

primary_outcome.measure: Feasibility defined as the proportion of patients 1) experiencing severe hypoglycemia (<40 mg/dL); 2) achieving glucose measurements within goal (110-180 mg/dL); and 3) experiencing nausea requiring discontinuation of exenatide therapy

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Calculated from hourly blood glucose samples starting at infusion initiation over 48 hours
secondary_outcome.measure: Mean glucose concentration during exenatide infusion

secondary_outcome.description: Calculated from hourly blood glucose samples starting at infusion initiation over 48 hours
secondary_outcome.measure: Number of glucose measurements within goal (110-180 mg/dL)/total number of glucose measurements

secondary_outcome.description: Calculated from hourly blood glucose samples starting at infusion initiation over 48 hours
secondary_outcome.measure: Mean time to reach glucose measurements within goal (110-180 mg/dL)

secondary_outcome.description: Calculated from hourly blood glucose samples starting at infusion initiation over 48 hours
secondary_outcome.measure: Glycemic variability defined as the standard deviation of glucose

secondary_outcome.description: Calculated from number of insulin units administered over 48 hours starting at infusion initiation

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of subjects requiring rescue insulin infusion protocol

secondary_outcome.description: Calculated from hourly blood glucose samples starting at infusion initiation over 48 hours
secondary_outcome.measure: Number of hypoglycemic episodes (<80 mg/dL)/total number of glucose measurements

secondary_outcome.description: Calculated from hourly blood glucose samples starting at infusion initiation over 48 hours
secondary_outcome.measure: Number of subjects with >1 episode of hypoglycemia (<80 mg/dL)/total number of subjects

secondary_outcome.description: Calculated from hourly microdialysis samples starting at infusion initiation over 48 hours
secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of patients experiencing metabolic crisis defined as cerebral microdialysate glucose concentration <0.7 mmol/L in combination with lactate pyruvate ratio >40

secondary_outcome.description: Calculated from hourly measurements starting at infusion initiation over 48 hours
secondary_outcome.measure: Mean daily intracranial and cerebral perfusion pressures

secondary_outcome.description: Calculated from hourly measurements starting at infusion initiation over 48 hours
secondary_outcome.measure: Number of hypotensive episodes (SBP<100 mmHg)/total number of blood pressure measurements

secondary_outcome.description: death, life-threatening event, prolonged hospitalization, disability or incapacity, congenital anomaly or birth defect, or important non-life threatening medical event
secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of patients experiencing serious adverse events

clinical_study.source: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

lead_sponsor.agency: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

clinical_study.study_design: Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment
